org.jpws.pwslib.data
Class PwsRecord

java.lang.Object
  org.jpws.pwslib.data.PwsRecord
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Cloneable
public class PwsRecord
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Cloneable

This class is a container for all data fields belonging to a PasswordSafe record. Not all fields have to be assigned a value, and the Record-ID - a UUID object that holds an immutable universal ID value - is by design always existent on a PwsRecord. A minimum set of non-empty fields must be assigned to a record in order to become "valid" (e.g. a requisite to get saved on a persistent file). These fields are: TITLE and PASSWORD.

Valid instances of this class can be added to and updated at a PwsRecordList object. Any iterator over instances of PwsRecord may be directly used to create a PasswordSafe file (persistent state) by using the PwsFileFactory.save() methods. There is no guarantee, however, that instances obtained from a PwsFile will be valid (files are allowed to load invalid records).

Transient Properties

The record property "ImportStatus" may be set by user or automatically through PwsRecordList.merge(). It is purely informational, but it is not reflected to the persistent state of a PwsFile.

Non-Canonical Fields (since 0-4-0)

Field types outside of the canon defined for the PWS file formats are supported in various ways. A) Non-canonical fields coming from other applications are tolerated and stored back to a persistent state when this record is saved. B) An application may utilize Extra Fields (one field value per type) by use of methods setExtraField() and getExtraField(). These fields also are part of the persistent state and the non-canonical field list.

Conventions:

Normalized Group Names. Group names, as values of the record field GROUP, may contain any sequence of valid group names separated by a "." character. No "." character is permitted at the beginning or end of the value. No empty elementary name is permitted (".."). The "." character always has the meaning of separating grouping levels and must not be used for elementary name expressions.

See Also:
PwsFileFactory

passwordUpdated

public void passwordUpdated()
This will set PASSMODTIME and ACCESSTIME to the actual time and should be called after a password value was modified. (For reasons of flexibility this is not automatically called when modifying a password through setPassword().)

addUnknownField

protected void addUnknownField(int id,
                               byte[] value)
Adds an unknown field value for this record for the purpose of conservation. In contrast to setExtraField() no validation is performed on the ID value. Does nothing if value is null. (This value is stored internally in cleartext during program session.)

Parameters:
id - field ID number (0..255)
value - field value (exact length)
Since:
0-4-0

setExtraField

public void setExtraField(int id,
                          byte[] value,
                          int format)
Inserts or sets a data field in this record which forms a non-canonical field identified by its integer type code. Only non-canonical field types may be entered; use the null value to clear the field from the list. Notes: This value is stored internally in cleartext during program execution. This method replaces any occurrence of a previously defined field with type id in the unknown field list. Whether a field value is canonical can be tested by PwsFileFactory.isCanonicalField().

Parameters:
id - non-canonical field ID number within 0..255
value - field value, or null to remove the field
format - the referenced file format version or 0 for default
Since:
0-4-0, 2-0-0 extended

public java.util.Iterator getUnknownFields()
Gets an iterator over all unknown fields stored for this record.

Returns:
Iterator of element type PwsRawField or null if no fields are listed
Since:
0-4-0 protected, 2-0-0 public

getCRC

public int getCRC()
Returns a CRC checkvalue for the contents of this record. (It may not be assumed that this value is identical over different releases of this software package. It may be assumed that it is identical over different program sessions with the same software package.)

Returns:
CRC32 integer incorporating all variable record elements

getSignature

public byte[] getSignature()
Renders a unique signature value of this record and its actual data state. Returns a SHA-256 checksum over all data content of this record. (Note that UUID is included in the integration, hence each record is guaranteed an individual value, regardless of its data content. It may be assumed - although there is no guarantee - that this value is identical over different releases of this software package and different sessions of a program running this package.)

Returns:
byte[] 32 byte signature value (SHA-256 digest)
Since:
2-0-0

setPassPolicyName

public void setPassPolicyName(java.lang.String policyName)
Sets a Password Policy Name for this record. This attempts to define the password policy via a template name, ranking over a directly supplied policy. (The template is to be defined in a file header value! The name here, however, can be supplied freely.)

Parameters:
policyName - String policy name
